message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and palpable mass suggest pyloric stenosis, which can be treated with pyloromyotomy. Surgical ligation of the fistula and primary end-to-end anastomosis of the esophagus is used to treat esophageal atresia. Duodenoduodenostomy is used to treat duodenal atresia. Endorectal pull-through procedure is used to treat Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings indicate pyloric stenosis, which is a common cause of vomiting in infants. The most appropriate surgical treatment for pyloric stenosis is pyloromyotomy, which involves a small incision in the muscle of the pylorus to relieve the narrowing. Options A, C, and D are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intermittent vomiting following feeding and the presence of a firm movable mass above and to the right of the umbilicus suggests pyloric stenosis. The most likely surgical treatment for this condition is pyloromyotomy, which involves a small incision in the muscle of the pylorus to relieve the obstruction. Option A is used for esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula. Option C is used for duodenal atresia. Option D is used for Hirschsprung's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant’s symptoms are suggestive of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is a narrowing of the outlet from the stomach to the small intestine. The only surgical treatment option listed for this condition is pyloromyotomy, which involves incising the thickened muscle at the lower end of the stomach to relieve the obstruction. Option A describes the surgical treatment for esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula. Option C describes the surgical treatment for duodenal atresia. Option D describes the surgical treatment for Hirschsprung’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical examination findings suggest pyloric stenosis. The most likely surgical treatment for this condition is pyloromyotomy, which involves cutting the muscle of the pylorus to relieve the obstruction. Surgical ligation of the fistula and primary end-to-end anastomosis of the esophagus is used to treat esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula. Duodenoduodenostomy is used to treat duodenal atresia, and endorectal pull-through procedure is used to treat Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest pyloric stenosis, which is managed by pyloromyotomy. Surgical ligation of the fistula and primary end-to-end anastomosis of the esophagus is for esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula. Duodenoduodenostomy is for duodenal atresia. Endorectal pull-through procedure is for Hirschsprung’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Pyloromyotomy is the surgical treatment of choice for this condition where the pylorus is narrowed and obstructed. Options A, C, and D are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pyloric stenosis, a condition in which the muscle surrounding the pylorus becomes hypertrophied and obstructs the passage of food from the stomach into the small intestine. The most likely surgical treatment for this condition is pyloromyotomy, a procedure in which a small incision is made in the muscle to relieve the obstruction. Surgical ligation of the fistula and primary end-to-end anastomosis of the esophagus is performed in cases of esophageal atresia. Duodenoduodenostomy is a procedure used to treat duodenal atresia. Endorectal pull-through procedure is used in the treatment of Hirschsprung's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of non-bilious vomiting immediately following feeding, along with the presence of a firm mass in the abdomen above and to the right of the umbilicus, suggest pyloric stenosis. The most likely surgical treatment for this condition is pyloromyotomy. The other options are not relevant to the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pyloric stenosis, which is treated with a pyloromyotomy procedure. Option A describes surgical treatment for esophageal atresia, Option C describes treatment for duodenal stenosis, and Option D describes treatment for Hirschsprung disease.
